title: Mixing Strobes and Continuous Light in Studio Photography
summary: Professional photographer Lindsay Adler explains the principles and workflow for combining strobe lighting with continuous lighting in a studio setting. She covers the practical reasons for mixing light sources, such as freezing motion or utilizing RGB colors, and demonstrates a step-by-step setup starting with the weakest light source to achieve a balanced exposure.

steps.action: Identify the weakest light source (typically the continuous light) and set it to 100% power to establish the baseline exposure.
Set the shutter speed. Do not exceed the camera's sync speed (usually 1/200s or 1/250s) when introducing a strobe.
Enable 'Exposure Simulation' on mirrorless cameras to preview the continuous light exposure in real-time.
Position the first continuous light (Nanlite PavoTube) and dial in camera settings (e.g., f/4, ISO 800, 1/200s) based on its output.
Add additional continuous lights for rim lighting and background color, stacking tubes if necessary for more power.
Eliminate all ambient room light (overheads, windows) so only the studio lights affect the exposure.
Add specific color accents using focused continuous lights (e.g., pink wash on background).
Introduce the strobe light (Profoto Pro-D3) to freeze the subject or act as the key light.
Balance the strobe power by turning it down significantly to match the weaker continuous lights.
If the strobe is still too bright at minimum power, use an ND (Neutral Density) gel to reduce its intensity.
Turn down or turn off the strobe's modeling light to prevent it from causing unwanted motion blur or ghosting in the image.

key_takeaways: Always build your exposure around the weakest light source first (usually the continuous light).
Shutter speed affects continuous light exposure but generally does not affect strobe exposure (below sync speed).
Strobes are essential for freezing motion when shooting at standard sync speeds (e.g., 1/200s) because continuous lights won't freeze fast movement.
Use ND gels to cut strobe power if the unit cannot be dimmed low enough to balance with continuous lights.
Ensure ambient light is completely controlled/removed to prevent interference.
